text.p: Creditanstalt Securities rated Hungarian pharmaceuticals company Horizon-Multiplan as "sell" and said the share was overvalued.

"We are convinced that fundamentally the share price cannot be justified. We believe Horizon-Multiplan shares are the most expensive stocks on the Budapest Stock Exchange, so we recommend their sale," said Daniel Straub, Creditanstalt Securities' Budapest-based analyst.
The average price/earnings ratio on the Hungarian market is just above nine based on 1996 forecasts and around seven based on 1997 estimated results, he said.
According to Creditanstalt Securities' estimates Horizon-Multiplan's P/E is 257 in 1996 and 64 in 1997, he said.
Horizon's share price has steadily risen from 154 forints at its listing on July 25, 1996 to 250 forints now, he said. The subscription price was 154 forints.
On Tuesday Horizon-Multiplan closed at 250 forints, up one.
The share's 154 forint subscription price was based on after-tax profit forecasts of 43 million, 371 million and 658 million forints for 1996, 1997 and 1998, respectively.

"It's questionable whether, after the IAS loss of 27 million forints in 1994, the 3.5 million forints profit in 1995 and the 1996 first half results, these profit forecasts are realistic," Straub said.

To achieve its forecast of a tripling of sales revenues in 1996, Horizon-Multiplan needs to sell 480,000 units of Humet-R -- a health supplement containing trace elements -- compared to 200,000 in 1995 and only 60,000 in the first seven months.

"Of course it can't be excluded that after the planned launch of foreign sales (in H2 1996), the rise in exports will somewhat compensate for a weaker performance on the domestic market. Still, the target of 480,000 units seems brave," Straub said.
